name: Finland
partner: Central European Institute of Asian Studies (CEIAS)
takeaway: China connections and cooperation have been decreasing in recent years in Finland. This is partly due to Covid-19 but also to increasingly critical views on China.

The Academia domain, in the form of reasearch cooperation, educaton export, and student exchange, has been a key area of cooperation with China, though education export has been winding down due to new foreign education related regulations in China.
Public data on sub-state level, startup investments, and thinktanks remains difficult to find.
description-1: In 2023, Finland had a GDP per capita of US$53,756 and a total population of 5.59 million people.
description-2: Finland established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1950. Finland was ranked 5th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 100/100.

Media.evidence: "赫尔辛基时报" has been started in Jan. 2021 until now(see the URL2 below). No obvious political contents, unlike the English language ‘China News’ section which has more political contents and mentions ‘cooperation with People's Daily Online’ but the editor is unreachable despite repeated attempts to inquire about the terms of contract over the past two years.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: In September 2019, Finland's largest newspaper Helsiging Sanomat (HS) published a frontpage add paid for by the Hong Kong SAR Government amplifying Beijing's propaganda about the HK protests. The editor of HS tried to defend its decision by claiming that social marketing falls under freedom of speech but it was very controversial among HS staff members and concerned segments of the wider public. In July 2021, HS and three other mainstream Nordic newspapers printed on their frontpage a common message of solidarity with Hong Kong's media freedom. No new evidence is available however.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: In the past there has been some individual cases of journalists being pressured by PRC officials.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: In this article, it is suggested that Finnish media may have been promoting Finnish businesses by avoiding to upset the Chinese government but the only supportive reference cited is Mari Manninen's 2019 book
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: A slight case of elite capture in January 2022 during the Winter Olympics boycott when former Finnish Prime Minister Esko Aho (also mentioned in a recent EU report as a case of elite capture by Moscow) was interviewed by CGTN to spread 'positive news' but no explicit doubting or denial of human rights abuses
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Tencent made one very large investment in Games Giant Supercell (84% acquired from SoftBank) and more recently fintech app Enfuce as well as earlier on in Finnish sportswear Amer with Chinese sportswear giant Anta
Technology.note: It is likely that this is done also more broadly  but this is difficult to verify from public reports.

Law Enforcement.evidence: Uncovered in spring 2013, a large-scale spying of the IT networks at the Finnish Ministry for Foreign Affairs focused on data traffic between Finland and the European Union and is believed to have continued for four years. A more recent large-scale cyberattack targeting the Finnish Parliament with the Finnish Security Intelligence Service (FSIS) revealing for the first time that the attack was of PRC origin. Chinese shippinig vessel is suspected of causing the disruption of an underwater gaspipe line.
